Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Interference-Aware Cooperation via Structured Codes: Creating an Empirical Cycle

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The classical approach to wireless communication is to isolate communication links by maximizing signal strength and minimizing interference between users. This simple philosophy is supported by a rich theoretical foundation which has inspired powerful coding techniques and protocols that lie at the heart of modern wireless systems. However, these systems have recently become victims of their own success as the rising density and data requirements of wireless devices have led to a surge in interference. Fortunately, an emerging body of work indicates that the phenomenon of interference may in fact represent an untapped opportunity for increasing the spectral and energy efficiency of next-generation wireless systems. Although many interference-aware communication strategies have been proposed in the literature, the promised gains have been mostly limited to the theoretical realm.

The objective of this project is to create practical interference-aware wireless protocols that can operate near the performance predicted by theoretical bounds in terms of throughput, energy efficiency, and reliability. The project is organized into three complementary thrusts that encompass theory, algorithms, and practice. The first thrust investigates lattice-based constellations and low-complexity codes for the compute-and-forward strategy, which enables receivers to decode linear combinations of transmitted codewords. Compute-and-forward can in turn be used as a building block for realizing interference-aware protocols such as physical-layer network coding and multiple-user MIMO (multi-input-uulti-output) systems. The second thrust aims to implement these protocols on a three-node WARP (Wireless Open-Access Research Platform) testbed. A series of carefully designed experiments will be used to compare the performance of interference-aware strategies while accounting for overhead costs. The third thrust leverages the data collected from these experiments to revise channel models to capture key features that impact the performance of interference-aware strategies such as asynchronism and channel fluctuations. These models will be used to revisit the theoretical foundations of interference-aware strategies and tailor them to the channels encountered in practice. This project features several outreach efforts including undergraduate research experiences connected to the WARP testbed and a public repository of training modules and videos.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When two or more users transmit simultaneously in a wireless network, the receiver observes a superposition of their emitted signals. This interference between users is usually viewed as an obstacle to reliable communication, and modern wireless systems are designed based on the principle of either avoiding interference or treating it as noise. However, interference is not simply noise: it is modulated data and often has the same constellation and code structure as the desired signal. Based on this idea, recent advances in the information theory literature have shown that the inherent structure of interference can sometimes be harnessed to attain higher throughputs in networks. The overarching goal of this project was to investigate whether this novel theoretical approach can deliver significant performance gains in practice.

Towards this end, we developed low-complexity architectures and algorithms for implementing the compute-and-forward strategy, which enables a receiver to recover linear combinations of simultaneously transmitted packets. We deployed our architecture on a WARP (Wireless Open-Access Research Platform) software-defined radio testbed as part of an integer-forcing multiple-antenna receiver. Integer-forcing uses compute-and-forward as a building block to recover multiple linear combinations, which it then solves for the interfering data packets. Through a series of experiments in an office environment, we compared the performance of this architecture to conventional approaches that treat interference as a source of noise. We found that, as predicted by prior theoretical and simulation studies, integer-forcing offers significant performance gains over conventional approaches. 

Another focus was on the development of algorithms that would enable integer-forcing to scale to larger networks, such as receivers with many antennas or cloud radio access networks. We proposed a fast algorithm for optimizing the beamforming and equalization matrices that are needed for integer-forcing multiple-antenna systems. We also demonstrated the viability of integer-forcing as a compression-based strategy for cloud radio access, which is emerging as a promising path for future network deployments.

As part of this project, three PhD students were trained as experts in wireless communications and two undergraduate students gained substantial experience with wireless algorithms through a summer project. The findings of this project were reported via conference and journal papers as well as seminars and conference papers. The code for implementing integer-forcing on the WARP testbed will be made publicly available.
